Mu-Jay Tai

New Taipei City, Taiwan · (886) 932-142320 · mujaytai@gmail.com

Welcome to my personal website. I am Mu-Jay.
I am a Electrical Engineering (EE) student at National Taiwan University (NTU).
My research area includes analog and digital IC design.
I was an intern at Intel and Apple'.

Also, I like to try new things and experience different cultures.

Let me share some delighted moments with you!

research

Analog IC Design


operational transconductance amplifier

Implemented an current-mirror operational transconductance amplifier (OTA) produced a large output swing under 0.8V supply voltage while achieving a gain-bandwidth product of 160-MHz, which verified its robustness under the ultra-deep-submicrometer regime.



Relaxation Oscillator

Surveyed different methods for enhancing Relaxation Oscillator frequency stability. [ document ]



Phase Lock Loop (PLL)

Researched methods to accelerate the locking speed of Phase Lock Loop (PLL). [ document ]


Digital IC Design

Ultra-Low Voltage Static Random Access Memory Design (SRAM)

Researched Ultra-Low Voltage Static Random Access Memory Design (SRAM) for lower energy loss in wearing device.



Adaptive FIR Noise Canceller

Implemented adaptive FIR filter model and Least mean squares (LMS) algorithms and taped out. The chip canceled 99 percent of the background noise to improve listening experience. [ code ]



Tank Battle

Implemented Verilog on FPGA and integrated FPGA peripheral modules, such as Arduino joystick and VGA image display process. [ code ]

Work

Apple Inc.

I was hired by Apple, Mac and Input Device team as a Product Design Intern on 10/2019. During the internship, I regularly traveled to Shanghai to join the new generation keyboard development in the front end laboratories. I met and collaborated with wonderful colleagues from different backgrounds and countries. I saw and learned how Apple works.

The below picture was the year-end party in 2020, and me standing in front of Apple.



Intel Corp.

I joined Intel, Communication and Device team on 01/2019. Our team mainly develop the WiFi and Bluetooth module. I enhanced my programming skills by completing an automation testing program that saved our team a lot of time.

The below picture was our team building, and me standing in front of Intel.

Stanford, American Language and Culture (ALC)

In my junior year, I attended Stanford’s ALC program. I honed my English speaking skills by taking the Effective Communication course, learning how to do a survey, and writing an essay by taking the Topic development course. I also visited D-school at Stanford and the leading companies in Silicon Valley, such as Facebook, Apple, and Google. I had an excellent time interacting with my ALC friends, and we still keep in touch now!


This experience broadened my horizons and totally changed my life. I met risk-taking people there. They are all willing to try new things and accept different sounds. Since then, I decided to take an adventurous life. I joined Intel and Apple. I was the leader of many events in my department. I enjoyed my life now!

LOVE Binti, Kenya [ website ]

LOVE Binti. project is held by STEP30, a Taiwanese organization committed to supporting people in East Africa for the long term. This project originated from discovering the lack of sanitary products for teenage Kenyan girls during menstrual cycles. They would use alternative things or even put themselves in prostitution to exchange a pack of sanitary pads. Therefore, we taught Kenya teenage girls to make reusable sanitary pads and conveyed the value of being women.


I accompanied kids in precious kids contre, an orphanage that accept disabled kids. Kenyan abandoned their functionally-disabled children because they think of difference from most people as a curse.

I also joined a family and did everything they did in one day, including chopping the wood, killing a chicken, cooking it, carrying water from far away to home, etc.

While experiencing severe cultural shock, I broadened my horizons. Knowing that there is somewhere different from where I live, I lowered myself and was more grateful to the resources I used to take for granted.

extracurricular activities

Not only did I work hard, but I also play hard. In my university life, I join many events in my department. I was the dancer in NTUEE night, dancing the waacking and girl’s style. I played the trumpet in the NTUEE orchestra. I also joined the NTUEE camp to teach students from high school to learn about EE. I made long-lasting friends from those events and enjoyed the time very much.
